_glossary.Brahma-vidya: Knowledge of Brahman, the supreme spiritual wisdom
_glossary.brahma-jijnasa: Inquiry into Brahman, the desire to know the Ultimate Reality
_glossary.karma: Action, work, or ritual; also refers to the law of cause and effect
_glossary.karma-kanda: The section of the Vedas dealing with rituals and actions
_glossary.shabda pramana: Scriptural testimony as a valid means of knowledge
_glossary.pramana: Valid means of knowledge or proof
_glossary.Brahman: The Ultimate Reality, Supreme Being, the infinite, eternal, and unchanging consciousness that is the source of all existence
_glossary.Vedanta: The end or culmination of the Vedas; philosophical teachings found in the Upanishads
_glossary.liberation: Freedom from the cycle of birth and death (moksha)
_glossary.Upanishad: Ancient philosophical texts forming the concluding part of the Vedas
_glossary.Vedas: Ancient Hindu scriptures, considered the ultimate authority in spiritual knowledge
_glossary.moksha: Liberation, the ultimate goal of spiritual practice - freedom from the cycle of birth and death

_section_tooltips.samshaya: The philosophical doubt or question that needs to be resolved
_section_tooltips.purvapaksha: The preliminary view or objection that is raised before establishing the final conclusion
_section_tooltips.prayojana: The purpose or benefit of this adhikarana discussion
_section_tooltips.vishaya: The main topic or subject matter under discussion in this adhikarana
_section_tooltips.siddhanta: The established conclusion or final verdict after examining all arguments

Adhikarana_1.name: जिज्ञासाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_1.वषय - Topic: The desire to know Brahman and the necessity of such inquiryℹ
Adhikarana_1.सशय - Samshaya: Is inquiry into Brahman necessary? Can one attain liberation through karma alone?
Adhikarana_1.परवपकष - Purvapaksha: Karma (ritualistic actions) alone is sufficient for liberation. There is no need for knowledge of Brahman.
Adhikarana_1.सधदनत - Siddhanta: Knowledge of Brahman is essential for liberation. Karma prepares the mind but cannot directly lead to moksha. Therefore, inquiry into Brahman (brahma-jijnasa) is necessary after acquiring the four-fold qualifications.
Adhikarana_1.notes: This is the first and foundational adhikarana that establishes the entire purpose of Vedanta study. The word 'atha' indicates auspicious beginning and 'athah' indicates sequence after karma-kanda.

Adhikarana_2.name: जन्माधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_2.वषय - Topic: The origin of the universe and Brahman as the source of creation, sustenance, and dissolution
Adhikarana_2.सशय - Samshaya: What is the meaning of 'janmādyasya yataḥ' (from which the origin etc. of this)? Does it refer to Pradhāna (primordial matter) or Brahman?
Adhikarana_2.परवपकष - Purvapaksha: Pradhāna (Prakṛti), the inert primordial matter of Sāṅkhya philosophy, is the cause of the universe. The word 'yataḥ' indicates material cause, not conscious cause.
Adhikarana_2.सधदनत - Siddhanta: Brahman alone is the cause of the universe - both material and efficient. The phrase 'janmādyasya yataḥ' means 'that from which the origin, sustenance, and dissolution of this universe proceeds.' Only omniscient Brahman, not inert Pradhāna, can be this cause because creation requires knowledge and deliberation (īkṣati).
Adhikarana_2.notes: This is the lakṣaṇa (definition) sūtra of Brahman. It establishes Brahman as both intelligent (nimitta) and material (upādāna) cause. The term 'janma' (birth/origin) implies systematic creation requiring consciousness.

Adhikarana_3.name: शास्त्रयोनित्वाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_3.वषय - Topic: The source of valid knowledge about Brahman
Adhikarana_3.सशय - Samshaya: Can Brahman be known through perception, inference, or other means of knowledge? Or are the scriptures the only source?
Adhikarana_3.परवपकष - Purvapaksha: Brahman can be known through inference and reasoning, similar to knowing the existence of atoms.
Adhikarana_3.सधदनत - Siddhanta: The Vedas (shabda pramana) are the only valid means of knowing Brahman. Brahman is beyond the reach of perception and inference as it transcends the sensory and intellectual realm.
Adhikarana_3.notes: This adhikarana establishes that scriptural testimony is indispensable for knowledge of Brahman, though reasoning can support and clarify scriptural teachings.
